title: Verbs followed by '-ing' or infinitive
introduction: Do you know when to use -ing and when to use to + infinitive after a verb? Test what you know with interactive exercises and read the explanation to help you.
explanation: A verb can be followed by another verb. The second one usually needs to change into the -ing form or the to + infinitive form. Which form you need depends on what the first verb is.
rules: ing form or the to + infinitive form. Which form you need depends on what the first verb is.
ing form and the to + infinitive form. They are both correct.
Verbs followed by to + infinitive form
it must be in the to + infinitive form.
keyPoints: enjoy, admit and mind are followed by another verb, it must be in the -ing form
want, learn and offer are followed by another verb, it must be in the to + infinitive form
examples: Do you know when to use -ing and when to use to + infinitive after a verb?
Look at these examples to see how the verb forms are used.
A verb can be followed by another verb.
When enjoy, admit and mind are followed by another verb, it must be in the -ing form.
I don't mind waiting if you're busy.
Other verbs in this group include avoid, can't help, consider, dislike, feel like, finish, give up, miss, practise and suggest.
Like and love can be followed by the -ing form and the to + infinitive form.
Verbs followed by to + infinitive form
When want, learn and offer are followed by another verb, it must be in the to + infinitive form.
He offered to help us wash up.
Other verbs in this group include afford, agree, ask, choose, decide, expect, hope, plan, prepare, promise, refuse and would like.
